conversations.content: The Dying Man's Words: Part One
In the south of Grastaea, there are areas which humans dare not enter. And Nidhogg's dwelling, the so- called ＂Rotten Spring,＂ is the most inaccessible of all these places.
The bubbling spring is acidic, and releases a constant fog of noxious gas that permeates the area and kills all life.
Nidhogg was the only being who could bathe in the water and live— so naturally he never had any visitors.
But one day, Nidhogg came across a man who was soaking in the spring. After a moment's hesitation, the man looked up at the dragon with bleary eyes and mumbled a short greeting.
Soon, his story was told: The man was once a noble, but after a rebellion, the new ruling powers sent him to die in the land of Nidhogg.
They told him it was befitting one of his stature to die beside a grand dragon.
＂I am not some puppet to be used in the petty quarrels of men,＂ growled Nidhogg.
＂Aw, don't be too upset,＂ chuckled the man as he gazed up at the massive figure of Nidhogg. ＂'Least I got to meet you before I die.＂
The man feared nothing—not even the dragon. For as he was already a dead man, what was there to fear?
＂I've no motive to kill you,＂ said Nidhogg. ＂But that gas will do its foul work ere long, and there will be not even bones left in the end.＂
The cursed dragon closed his black wings and examined the man, who suddenly realized that Nidhogg did not bring death—he was merely an observer to it over the eons.
The man was then filled with curiosity about the dragon, and decided to use his final moments asking questions of him.
The Dying Man's Words: Part Two
As his body began to melt into the Rotten Spring, the man felt no pain or fear. Instead, he was gripped by an intense curiosity about the locale's ruler, Nidhogg.
＂Will you die, dragon?＂ he asked.  ＂I know not,＂ replied Nidhogg.
＂Are you envious of the dead, then?＂  ＂Why would you ask this of me, human?＂
＂Because of the great interest you are taking in me,＂ said the man with a rattling wheeze. ＂And yet, to you, my life should be as insignificant as a maggot on a rotted apple.＂
＂I merely thought that a creature who did not know death might envy one who does. But it seems your endless life has made you apathetic.＂
＂How foolish,＂ snorted Nidhogg. ＂Death is the end of the flesh, nothing more. Being free from its skeletal grip does not make life any more or less significant.＂
＂You consider life and death to be intrinsically linked because you must. To think otherwise at the moment of your end would invite madness.＂
The man laughed weakly. ＂You're a tough nut to crack, dragon. But let me ask you something as an impartial observer to life and death: Is there a world beyond this one?＂
Nidhogg grew silent, for the man had finally asked a question to which he had no answer. He could administer death. He had watched it countless times. But he could not experience it.
The man laughed, delighted. ＂To tell the truth, I'm excited. I never asked to be born into nobility, and was always envious of the explorers who journeyed into the unknown.＂
＂And now I've found a journey where even the wisest of dragons can't say what awaits me at the end! If this be my final moment, it is a fine one indeed.＂
With that, the man exhaled a final breath and slowly sank into the spring. Nidhogg watched over the spot where he had been for a long while, then returned to his slumber.
The man had set off to a new world.  But nothing changed for Nidhogg.  And nothing ever would.
